rec08nvLPxJrRrW6t.Name: goalsleepschedule1.1
rec08nvLPxJrRrW6t.Bottom Body:
We want to help you reach your goal of sticking to a sleep schedule. 

**Defining your goal**
A solid sleep schedule helps your body's rhythms stay aligned which leads to better quality sleep. However, sleep is complicated and sticking with a schedule can be tricky. 

To get you started, we're going to talk about two things you can do to help you stick with your sleep schedule!

1. **Get alarmed**  
2. **Don't nap**

rec0BOKymdnFbmDmL.Name: Architecture 1.4
rec0BOKymdnFbmDmL.Bottom Body:
There, you did it!! You’ve completed Sleep Basics 101, the first step to becoming an expert sleeper. 

At this point, we have thrown a lot of information at you. You’re probably thinking that sleep seems complicated, but some of the solutions to better sleep are actually pretty simple. 

There are a lot of different things you can do to optimize your sleep. Stick with Reboot Camp to learn how!

rec0HNu4bd7FsFyEK.Name: Supplements 1.4
rec0HNu4bd7FsFyEK.Bottom Body:
**What about melatonin?**

Melatonin is the most popular sleep supplement

But it’s often overused. 

Long-term use of melatonin supplements may deplete your natural production of melatonin. Additionally, most doses are **way too high**. If you do need to take it, stick with a dose of 0.3 mg, which more closely mimics your body’s natural production and has been shown to be more effective than higher doses. 

Ideally, save your melatonin supplement for when you have jet-lag or after an all-nighter!

rec0HxJAjQKeeybgR.Name: relearn 1.4
rec0HxJAjQKeeybgR.Bottom Body:
**2. Leave the bed when you can’t sleep**

Staying in bed when you can't sleep can lead your mind to associate bed with activities like rumination, stress, mental anguish, and existential dread. 

As a rule, if you are laying in bed trying to sleep and it’s been longer than 20 minutes – leave the bed!

**Where do you go?** Ideally, go somewhere that you can relax and do something boring. You can head to your living room, a cozy nook, or any room other than your bedroom. 

Later on, we'll give you some really cool ideas for an in-home cozy space!

For now, the important thing is to just get out of bed!

rec0QDxgXPSHSEV6X.Name: to know you 1.1
rec0QDxgXPSHSEV6X.Bottom Body:
We want to get to know you better. We'll regularly drop by with questions that help us learn more about you and your needs. 

As you may have already noticed, needs change sometimes! So, we'll regularly check in to make sure you're getting the advice you need. 

Let's learn a little bit about you...

rec0YLjhtSKaQxiQ1.Name: Quickwin4.3
rec0YLjhtSKaQxiQ1.Bottom Body:
First of all, you should dim the lights in your environment two hours before bed. That's when your body begins to produce melatonin for sleep. 

Next, for the next-level melatonin surge – swap out your bedside light for a red light bulb. Research has found that red light doesn't disrupt melatonin and may actually boost it! Cool, right?

rec0eZu1xIjbieNVz.Name: goalqual 1.2
rec0eZu1xIjbieNVz.Bottom Body:
**1. Move it** 
Exercise has a lot of health benefits. It also happens to be one of the best ways to optimize your sleep!

Exercise has been shown to increase the amount of time you spend in restorative slow-wave sleep. Physical activity has also been shown to reduce stress by 40%, which also helps get them high quality Zzzzs. 

**How much do I need?** Ideally, aim for at least 150 minutes a week with at least 90 minutes at moderate intensity (80% of your maximum heart rate). Strength training and aerobic exercise are both helpful to sleep!

rec0flhG1rmgVWXNL.Name: Exercise 1.3
rec0flhG1rmgVWXNL.Bottom Body:
**How does exercise help you sleep better?**
- It helps you sleep longer and more efficiently
- It helps you fall asleep more quickly
- It increases the amount of restorative deep sleep you get

Exercise also helps reduce sleep apnea, lowers your stress response, improves blood flow, and helps regulate your circadian rhythm. Exercise even boosts serotonin which helps regulate mood and sleep. 

The health benefits of exercise are numerous and can improve your sleep in many ways. 

Let’s take a look...

rec0i4gRmzTOmhUT4.Name: Why 1.3
rec0i4gRmzTOmhUT4.Bottom Body:
**Adaptations**
Unlike certain other animals, humans have evolved neurological tricks in the face of severe sleep deprivation (similar to some birds and aquatic mammals).

**What tricks?** The human brain has the ability to shut down certain parts while sort of staying awake. 

Think of it as microsleeps. They aren't as helpful as a real sleep, but it keeps things going in the face of severe sleep deprivation. 

A sleep-deprived state is not how you want to live, but it's nice to know that lack of sleep won't kill you. 

Remind your brain about Mrs. Weston every time it starts acting up with drama on sleepless nights! 

**Ok, if my brain is planning on keeping me alive, why is it being so dramatic when I can't sleep?**

rec18aKzlmZHk8Jzv.Name: Wokeuptired 1.5
rec18aKzlmZHk8Jzv.Bottom Body:
This doesn’t uncover all of the mysteries of feeling tired. It doesn’t always mean you slept poorly, it could just be an off day. 

So, what do you do when you wake up groggy?

Let’s explore some ways to get that energy up!

rec1LEssYchwvDJiw.Name: Lighting 1.1
rec1LEssYchwvDJiw.Bottom Body:
Are you ready to talk about lighting? Of course you’re ready to talk about lighting. 

As you may recall, light is the most important environmental cue to your circadian rhythm. Your exposure to light in the morning, daytime and evening all impacts how well you sleep.

To recap, here’s what we’ve covered so far:

1. Darkness is one of the most important cues for sleep
2. Exposure to bright light before bed or during the night can disrupt sleep and suppress melatonin levels.
3. Black out curtains and sleep masks are awesome for blocking environmental light while you sleep.

Great!

Now let’s move onto some extra tips for dealing with environmental light **before** bedtime!

rec1MLZ1RfMKEenFl.Name: QuickwinFA8.3
rec1MLZ1RfMKEenFl.Bottom Body:
**The 54321 method!**

You can use this method any time you feel stressed. It can be super helpful on those nights when you are laying in bed with a busy mind that just won’t seem to shut off. 

**How does it work?** Normally, this grounding technique uses the environment around you to name various objects that appeal to your senses. However, when doing it from bed, you’ll be relying on your imagination (or memory). 

**Simply imagine** 
- **5 things you can see**
- **4 things you can feel**
- **3 things you can hear**
- **2 things you can smell**
- **1 thing you can taste**

Take your time and try to truly visualize and experience each of the senses. 

If you want to repeat it, use your imagination to transport you to another room, planet, or dimension and do it all over again!

rec1RiV4wZChj1Onm.Name: goalsleepschedule1.4
rec1RiV4wZChj1Onm.Bottom Body:
Sticking to a schedule can be tricky. A lot of times it comes down to discipline. 

When those mornings come and you want to hit snooze, or something is good on Netflix and you want to stay up late, just ask yourself – "does this bring me closer to my goals?"

By obeying the call of your alarms and skipping daytime naps, you'll be able to move toward your goal of sticking with a sleep schedule.

rec1ZPph9HiyDR3JO.Name: wakingup 1.3
rec1ZPph9HiyDR3JO.Bottom Body:
**Get started**
You should aim to journal somewhere within an hour before bedtime. Right before you go to sleep is fine!

Grab a journal, a pen you enjoy, and take 10-20 minutes to journal out your to-do list before you plan to sleep. 

If there's a looming duty that you have no action plan for, simply write "will revisit tomorrow". This allows your brain to close the curtain on that item. 

**ok, let's look at the next part of your action plan..**.

rec1lOxSxmZGx756a.Name: Sleepstress 1.4
rec1lOxSxmZGx756a.Bottom Body:
When everything is in order, by the end of the day, these systems work together to send you off to slumberville. 

When there is a mismatch in signalling, you can experience sleep-disrupting scenarios where you feel sleepy but alert, or simply don’t feel tired when you should. 

Learning how to use your own biology along with cues from your environment can help you regain control of your sleep. You can quite literally program yourself to sleep better.

rec27YMtpBP3XSQMN.Name: caffeineSleep 1.3
rec27YMtpBP3XSQMN.Bottom Body:
**Rule # 2** 
**Don't drink caffeine too late in the day**

Drinking caffeine after 2 pm can significantly disrupt your nightly slumber. Even if you feel like you sleep ok, it can decrease the quality of sleep you get. 

**Why?** It can take your body 8- 14 hours to metabolize caffeine. If you drink 200 mg of coffee at 5 pm, by 10 pm there’s still 100 mg kicking around inside of you

**TIP:** Decaf has 15 to 30% of the caffeine dose of a regular cup of coffee! Also, watch out for sneaky caffeine in sodas, over-the-counter medication, chocolates, treats, and teas.

rec2fQEAYd3qpwDUc.Name: Quickwin 1.3
rec2fQEAYd3qpwDUc.Bottom Body:
**Quick win of the day**

Did you know that taking a warm shower or bath one hour before bed can help you fall asleep up to 36% faster? It's true! 

But why? Your body sleeps better when it's cool. Believe it or not, a warm shower or bath actually cools your core temperature, making ideal conditions for sleep!

ummmm, wait, what? how?

rec2odlnU7CZhqiKZ.Name: QuickwinFA 1.1
rec2odlnU7CZhqiKZ.Bottom Body:
It's time for your first Quick Win! 

_Wait_, what the heck is a Quick Win again?

In case you forgot, Quick Wins will appear throughout your journeys. They are tiny habits, behaviors, or facts that help give you a boost in your journey toward better sleep!

rec2sLWwQesqmnj7y.Name: Why 1.1
rec2sLWwQesqmnj7y.Bottom Body:
Being unable to sleep sucks. Have you ever wondered why it feels like your mind is in such great turmoil when you can't sleep?

**It's because your brain is a little dramatic!**
You may have already noticed that trouble sleeping is often paired with catastrophic thoughts like:

- "my life is ruined if I can't sleep"
- "I'm going to die if I don't sleep"
- "ughhggaargghhhhhhhhhh"

**Physiological needs**
Here's the thing – sleep is an essential need. Just like how suddenly being unable to swallow might make you panic, being unable to sleep can also lead your brain to make dramatic conclusions. 

However, just like you won't die if you can't eat for a day, or week or even a month – missing sleep won't kill you. 

**wait, REALLY?**
rec2sLWwQesqmnj7y.Top Body: ## I can't sleep and it sucks

rec3cnGIaE7fphYdO.Name: QuickwinFA 8.1
rec3cnGIaE7fphYdO.Bottom Body:
It’s that time again! Time for another Reboot Camp Quick Win!

Yay!

This one is awesome because you can do it while you’re already all comfy in your bed. 

Are you ready to hear how another classic grounding technique can help you sleep faster at night?

rec3cvWpT4CAw4QWx.Name: Circadian 1.8
rec3cvWpT4CAw4QWx.Bottom Body:
Now you’ve learned how various environmental cues can impact your circadian rhythm. 

Living in a modern society means that our environmental cues are no longer all taken from nature. With artificial light sources, confined work schedules, and common “bad” habits, it’s easy to see how so many people have circadian rhythms that are misaligned.

The true secret to better sleep is learning how to live in modern society and still work with your body’s natural rhythms. 

It takes some time to figure out, but we’re here to help you every step along the way.

rec3nwvtSEl84IQCy.Name: Decompression 1.4
rec3nwvtSEl84IQCy.Bottom Body:
**Journal!**

Journaling is a very effective and scientifically supported way to reduce stress that might be keeping you up at bedtime.

By setting aside 10-20 minutes to journal every night, you will allow your mind to decompress and give yourself closure for the day!

Vent your thoughts, make notes about your day, create a to-do list for tomorrow, or just write whatever randomly pops into your mind!

Check out this [article](https://intercom.help/rested-health/en/articles/5128187-journal-your-way-to-better-sleep) for more details.

**Are you ready for one more decompression tip?!**

rec3pgKM2haYvx8UZ.Name: sneaky 1.3
rec3pgKM2haYvx8UZ.Bottom Body:
You may have guessed that caffeine and sleep don't mix so well. However, what you may not have known is that caffeine shows up in a lot of common foods, supplements and beverages. 

**Why should you care?**
It takes your body from 8-14 hours to metabolize caffeine. This means that it can impact your sleep long after you consume it. For instance, drinking two diet sodas in the evening is equivalent to a cup of coffee!

**Much too much** 
High doses of caffeine (>400mg), even if consumed earlier in the day, can also interfere with sleep quality. This is because caffeine blocks adenosine, a chemical that helps regulate sleep. 

So, where is caffeine sneaking in?

rec42uL51DzTuGrik.Name: Noise 1.3
rec42uL51DzTuGrik.Bottom Body:
You may struggle to eliminate all of the noises in your sleeping environment, such as a partner snoring or if you live too close to a high-traffic area. 

Luckily, we have some tips to help with that!

Want to hear the first tip?

rec4535QoX49k2Zx4.Name: Bedroom 1.3
rec4535QoX49k2Zx4.Bottom Body:
**Black out curtains!**

Even if the sun has gone down, there can still be environmental light such as street lights that can impede on your circadian rhythm. 

Blackout curtains will block any light pollution from your environment (which can be extremely helpful for shift workers or anyone who many need to sleep during daylight).

Not ready to invest in new curtains? Don’t worry, we have another tip...

rec49BsVZAmMxgjj3.Name: spower 1.4
rec49BsVZAmMxgjj3.Bottom Body:
**Your brain on sleep**
As you slumber each night, your brain stays very active. What's it doing?

Each night your brain goes through several unique stages of activity that each come with their own benefits. 

**Sleep is when your brain stays busy:**
- Clearing out toxic waste and byproducts
- Normalizing connections (called synapses) to prepare your brain for new experiences
- Storing memories
- Processing and regulating emotions 
- Reorganizing thoughts and experiences (it even boosts creativity)


Want to know a fun fact?

rec4ObqOdaNoXCLRC.Name: Onboarding1.2
rec4ObqOdaNoXCLRC.Bottom Body:
In order to become a true sleep master, we’ll need to get aligned on sleep language and basic sleep knowledge. Even if you feel like you already know it all, a little review is helpful (plus, you might learn something new!)

To kick things off, we’ll cover:
1. **Circadian rhythm**
2. **Sleep drive**
3. **Sleep architecture**

Let's go!

rec4PDyGtI4bfaEE9.Name: BasicsQ 1.5
rec4PDyGtI4bfaEE9.Bottom Body:
Next, let's take a moment to remember everything you learned about "Your relationship with sleep"

If you recall, this journey looked at your relationship with sleep! It's complicated. 

Let's take the quiz...

rec4Rn9pCzzikTlxb.Name: Mornings 1.1
rec4Rn9pCzzikTlxb.Bottom Body:
Do you ever find it hard to get out of bed in the morning?

Have you ever ran headfirst into your day feeling overwhelmed before noon?

Morning rituals can help with that. 

Developing a morning ritual is an excellent way to boost your mornings, get more out of your day, and promote better sleep at night. Even if you aren’t a morning person, there’s still a routine for you!

Let’s take a look at how morning rituals can improve your life...

rec4XY57ZccDrv3jg.Name: quickwins 3.1
rec4XY57ZccDrv3jg.Bottom Body:
It's time for another handy-dandy quick win!

We see you out there trying to make positive changes in your life. It can be hard sometimes, right?

We want you to be successful, so today's quick win is one that will help you more easily build new habits...

rec4aqqQbOnIzh5Hc.Name: Waketime 1.2
rec4aqqQbOnIzh5Hc.Bottom Body:
**The importance of waking up at the same time every day**

Here’s the thing, it’s very difficult to go to bed at the same time every night. That means waking up at the same time every day is your number one key to regulating your circadian rhythm.

**But, I wanna sleep in!?!?**
Yes, it can be a pain. Yes, you sacrifice sleep from time to time. But, it’s actually worth it! Once you get over the difficult part, you will reap the many benefits to gain from optimizing your circadian rhythm. 

Your body is designed to function this way and it will help optimize all your body processes that run on a circadian rhythm. That’s basically everything. 

So, make sure you stick to this one. Set your alarm in advance so that it goes off at the same time every day. 

And just get on up and start your day. You won’t regret it.

rec4g2kytTeEJnpE4.Name: Orientation 1.2
rec4g2kytTeEJnpE4.Bottom Body:
**Pace yourself**
If you’re loving Reboot Camp and psyched to keep going at a faster pace, great! If you’re enjoying Reboot Camp but you’d prefer to learn at a slower pace, that’s also great! 

There is no wrong way to do it as long as you’re committed to better sleep. 

This next part is going to focus on **YOU** and **your relationship with sleep**.

And we’re going to start reeeeeally basic.

rec4qkyEVDh46H7VH.Name: Substances 1.4
rec4qkyEVDh46H7VH.Bottom Body:
Drinking too much coffee or drinking it too late in the day can disrupt your body’s natural processes for sleep and keep your system in a state of arousal long after the caffeine buzz has worn off. 

**Why?**

**Because caffeine is slowly metabolized**

Did you know that it can take your body **8- 14 hours** to metabolize caffeine? This means that if you have any caffeine after 2 pm it can leave you buzzing into bedtime. 

As an example, if you drink 200 mg of coffee at 5 pm, by 10 pm there’s still 100 mg kicking around inside of you. Yeesh.

rec4wrnNxQJAbmoKN.Name: Unlearn 1.4
rec4wrnNxQJAbmoKN.Bottom Body:
Remember subconscious sleep stress? It can lead to chronic sleep problems.

**Sleep stress leads to sleep stress**
In the same way that watching TV in bed leads your brain to associate TV + Bed, stressing in bed over being unable to sleep leads to chronic sleep problems.

**Why?** Because being stressed out in bed over the inability to sleep leads to a program in your brain that anticipates the inability to sleep. 

**Journey with us a moment:**
Imagine this...It's 2 am, you're trying to sleep and just cannot fall asleep. You feel stressed, angry, overwhelmed and you lay in bed cursing the sleep gods.

Your brain then begins creating a new program: 
- "cursing the sleep gods" + "bed"  

After a few times, your mind will then anticipate stress and inability to sleep with your bed! The more it happens – the stronger the links grow.

rec4yNX5IPxWfCqCk.Name: goalfallasleepfaster1.5
rec4yNX5IPxWfCqCk.Bottom Body:
Like with everything else, we don't expect you to perfect these two things immediately.

However, it's really important that you begin to learn the difference between fatigue and sleepiness  – and only go to bed with you are sleepy! 

It won't fix your difficulties falling asleep immediately, but, these steps are your keys to retraining your mind and body for sleep.

rec4yxFHdcn1jRJEu.Name: quickwinFA 3.1
rec4yxFHdcn1jRJEu.Bottom Body:
It's time for another handy-dandy quick win!

As you begin to implement some new habits that bring you closer to your goal of falling asleep faster, it can be hard. Change isn't always easy!

We want you to be successful, so today's quick win is one that will help you more easily build new habits...

rec51ha979IyQNzFt.Name: Circadian 1.6
rec51ha979IyQNzFt.Bottom Body:
**Eating**
Your circadian rhythm enjoys a consistent schedule and eating at unusual times can disrupt it. 

The relationship between the timing of meals and your circadian rhythm is primarily controlled by insulin. Your metabolism shifts throughout the day and most people benefit by eating larger meals earlier in the day.

Skipping breakfast, eating large meals late at night, and fasting can all be disruptive to your circadian rhythm. However, everyone is unique. 

The most important factor with eating is to remain fairly consistent in your mealtimes.

rec53W2D7doD56QPy.Name: general 1.3
rec53W2D7doD56QPy.Bottom Body:
**Visualization or guided imagery**

This powerful decompression technique uses your imagination to transport yourself to peaceful and relaxing settings. Studies have found that visualizing an experience can lead to patterns of brain activity that mirror how your brain reacts to the real-life experience!

**Get started**
The easiest way is to use a guided track that's targeted at stress reduction or relaxation. 

If you feel comfortable, you can try it on your own.

**Here's how...**

rec55eyEQdxG8Kcos.Name: Electronics 1.6
rec55eyEQdxG8Kcos.Bottom Body:
**A little recap**
So, basically, the human eye loves blue light and does a terrible job blocking it. 

As a result, nearly all the blue light in your environment passes straight to the back of your retina where it sends signals to your brain (like “HEY, BE ALERT!)

Now, we don’t expect you to toss all of your electronics and lightbulbs into the sea, so let’s look at how to minimize the impact of blue light on your sleep!

rec58ZhSkmVcUqKrz.Name: Substances 1.3
rec58ZhSkmVcUqKrz.Bottom Body:
First, we’ll start with caffeine. 

**Caffeine and sleep**
Caffeine is a stimulant. You probably already know that.

It pumps you up by boosting adrenaline. It also reduces melatonin. These are perfectly fine qualities for the morning. 

Another way caffeine makes you feel alert is by blocking adenosine (remember, that’s what builds sleep pressure all day!).

So, how does this affect your sleep?

rec5NcSaBv2JcfLFZ.Name: Noise 1.6
rec5NcSaBv2JcfLFZ.Bottom Body:
So, now you know that environmental noise can impede on your sleep and mess with your deep restorative sleep. Boooooo!

But! You can eliminate environmental noise by using a **sound machine** or **ear plugs**! Yaaaaaay!

Ok, cool. Let’s journey on and find out more sweet facts about your sleep environment!

rec5TYEjPSvhfbyxv.Name: relearn 1.5 copy
rec5TYEjPSvhfbyxv.Bottom Body:
**When leaving your bed because you can’t sleep:**
1. **Don’t use your phone, computer or watch TV:** These will all suppress your melatonin and make it harder to fall asleep. The only exception is cueing up a podcast or meditation track to help you relax.
2. **Don’t fall asleep in the new location:** As soon as you feel tired again, head back to bed and try for round 2.
3. **Do something relaxing/boring:** Try reading or listening to the radio or an audiobook. You can also do a meditation track, some light stretching, or yoga.  
4. **Low light:** Stay away from bright lights to help your body know that it's not "wake-up" time. Dimmers and motion-sensor nightlights are great tools for this!

If you head back to bed and have trouble sleeping again, repeat the process. You’ll keep repeating it until you finally find sleep (we realize this sounds awful, but it works).

rec6WelE3jeaCZKO2.Name: Sleepstress 1.2
rec6WelE3jeaCZKO2.Bottom Body:
To better understand sleep, it's important that you understand some of the biological processes that drive sleep!

We won't expect you to be an expert and we'll give you cool graphs to make it more fun.

To kick things off, let's look at the two main processes that drive your need for sleep! 

**Sleep drive** and **Circadian Alerting System**

rec6eOufcqKZzaQIp.Name: Oriented 1.1
rec6eOufcqKZzaQIp.Bottom Body:
Before we tell you about the journey ahead, let's introduce you to your Rested Health support system.

Within Rested Health you have access to:
1. **Journey Cards**
2. **Sleep Library**
3. **Sleep Coach**

What does each of these contain? Let's take a look!

rec75P8wX7fGqs6dm.Name: Tracking 1.9
rec75P8wX7fGqs6dm.Bottom Body:
**Head wearables**

They come equipped with sensors that measure brain wave activity (similar to devices used in sleep study labs). 

**Popular Head wearables:**
- **Headband** (Dreem, Muse, Sleep Sheppard)
- **Smart Sleepmask** (Neuroon sleepmask)

**Pros:** They offer information that used to only be available through sleep studies and can more accurately measure sleep cycles.

rec7AsvfTrCyXBh2P.Name: BedtimeBasics 1.7
rec7AsvfTrCyXBh2P.Bottom Body:
**Sleeping in a warm room is disruptive to the quality of sleep you get**.  

A warm temperature might make you feel warm and cozy, but it goes against your body’s natural sleep state. 

Here’s the deal, your circadian rhythm causes your body to cool down at night and continue cooling until the wee hours of the morning. This is to optimize melatonin and maintain quality sleep. 

Therefore, sleeping in a room with **a cooler temperature will give you a better quality of sleep.**

Research has found that sleeping in warmer rooms reduces sleep quality and quantity. 

The exact temperature is personal, but there is an official ideal temperature for sleep that you should try and stick with. 

So, what temperature should you set it to?

rec7JN0jev2VA7sQ0.Name: models 1.6
rec7JN0jev2VA7sQ0.Bottom Body:
**4. Unconsciously competent**: "I know how to fix my problem and I've been practicing a lot so my habits feel automatic"

Look at us, we're at the top of the ladder! It's nice up here!

The final rung on the competence ladder is when your new habits and skills become automatic. That means, they don't require so much mental energy to do.

You now have confidence in your new skill! 

**Can I get off the ladder now?**
No! If you stop practicing your new skills, you'll end up sliding back down the ladder. 

Improving your sleep is just like any other skill, there's no true ceiling. Just like if you went through bootcamp to get fit, you'd need to keep working out in order to stay fit. 

However, those new habits and skills you build become your **foundation for good sleep**. 

Sound good?

rec7JdQzFsclOQ268.Name: change 1.4
rec7JdQzFsclOQ268.Bottom Body:
**2. Scope**

Another common mistake people make is being unrealistic in the scope of their goals. By diving headfirst into too many changes, you are more likely to fail. 

**How do I avoid it?**
As you begin implementing changes that bring you closer to your goals, have patience. Setting smaller achievable goals and making tiny changes will set you up for success. We'll help you out. 

**It's raining wins**
Those daily small wins add up and bring you closer to where you want to be. 

The author of Atomic Habits, James Clear put it this way:
"If you get one percent better each day for one year, you’ll end up thirty-seven times better by the time you’re done"

rec7XviUOwXrDCV2Y.Name: Orientation 2.5
rec7XviUOwXrDCV2Y.Bottom Body:
**Getting basic**
We’re still going to be focusing on some basics along with a few little advanced techniques.

If you’re already a basics-of-sleep genius, you may have heard a lot of this stuff before. Don’t shoot the messenger! Just think of this as a refresher and give yourself a big ol pat on the back!

If you learn even _one _new thing that can help improve your relationship with sleep, you’re already winning!

rec86kRwZekvonnkT.Bottom Body:
