recMQ81IaEXJ8YcZD.Name: Tracking 1.1
recMQ81IaEXJ8YcZD.Bottom Body:
Doing work while you’re asleep can be tricky. 

The traditional way for people to track their sleep is by using a **sleep diary**. However, it can be pretty difficult for people to accurately track their own sleep. 

**Technology to the rescue!**
There is now an abundance of wearable tracking devices that not only measure your daily activity but also monitor your sleep quality, duration, and wake-up times!

recMRfyh1lFWjAsrE.Name: racingmind 1.3
recMRfyh1lFWjAsrE.Bottom Body:
**Step 2:** With your hand still on your heart, slowly repeat this mantra – "I am at peace"

As you say the words inside your mind, make an effort to believe them. Notice the comfort of your bed, the steady and smooth beat of your heart, and sink into the feeling of peace.

recMiiX4cYu0QOPqO.Name: spower 1.1
recMiiX4cYu0QOPqO.Bottom Body:
You now understand the basics of learning by association and how that can negatively impact our sleep.

As you may have expected, we'll be asking you to make some changes in order to help you sleep better. 

- **Is it worth it?**

- **Will better sleep actually change your life?**

- **Will you actually gain any health benefits?**

Let's take a look at sleep – your superpower.

recMrSPlvxqKUdtZl.Name: Substances 1.1
recMrSPlvxqKUdtZl.Bottom Body:
**Don’t let your daytime ruin your night**

Learning about which daytime activities can impact sleep can help you make better choices as you go about your day. 

You may have already heard that certain substances we consume can have a negative impact on sleep...but is it really such a big deal?

Let’s explore the two most popular daytime substances that impact sleep:

**Caffeine and alcohol**

recN1Cuxci9I3X90s.Name: Quickwin 11.4
recN1Cuxci9I3X90s.Bottom Body:
**Waking up is easier with light**
You can set a light alarm to your preferred wake-up time and allow your body to gently stir awake to a lovely sun-like glow each morning. 

Not only can a light alarm wake you up naturally, but if used on a regular basis can also strengthen your sleep-wake cycle!

See? Not all alarms are mean. Level up your morning by grabbing yourself a little simulation sunrise!

recNCpdLnkhCLJnvA.Name: Circadian 1.4
recNCpdLnkhCLJnvA.Bottom Body:
**Light**

Light intake is the **_most_** important environmental influence for adjusting your sleep-wake cycle. It’s #1. Numero uno. It is the king of zeitgebers.

Cells in your eyes (specifically, your retina) measure the amount of light in your environment and then send signals directly to your SCN. Light results in a signal to stop melatonin production and boost wakefulness. 

Similarly, darkness results in the opposite effect. During the evening, your body is programmed to release melatonin. Darkness acts as a cue to allow the secretion of melatonin. 

That’s why dim lighting before bed is helpful for making you sleepy!

recNFuQ2zi7lCz2Oc.Name: QuickwinFA4.2
recNFuQ2zi7lCz2Oc.Bottom Body:
**What to do about light at night**

Here's the good news: We don't expect you to wear night vision goggles

Here's the tough news: You may need some new light bulbs

OK, that wasn't so bad. Was it? 

Here's a quick tip on how to avoid messing up your sleep with too much light before bedtime...

recNJ9fb3BB3KeNsb.Name: unlearn 1.2
recNJ9fb3BB3KeNsb.Bottom Body:
Your brain is constantly scanning your surroundings and updating its “files.” These files contain information and protocols that are meant to make your life easier. 

**Passive learning**
If two separate events occur together repeatedly (sometimes even just once) your brain associates them. This is why certain scents are linked to memories and also why dogs freak out when they see you grab their leash. 

This cognitive short-cut makes learning (and life) easier! Except when unwanted associations get formed 
\*cue sad trombone sound\*

**Active Unlearning**
Don't worry, you can also unlearn associations between things, although it tends to take a little longer than learning them. 

**So, how does this impact my sleep?**

recNV7dHDo7cVU9Ja.Name: irrationalThoughts 1.3
recNV7dHDo7cVU9Ja.Bottom Body:
**Step 1: Identify the thought-** "I'm going to get sick and die if I don't fall asleep"

**Step 2: List evidence for or against it**- 
**Evidence for:** Losing sleep can weaken your immune system and sometimes makes you feel off.
**Evidence against:** Nobody has ever died from lack of sleep. I've missed sleep before and it didn't kill me.

**Step 3: Reframing the thought-** "If I don't sleep well I may not feel my best tomorrow"

As you can see, the reframed version of the original thought doesn't quite carry the same emotional burden!

recNcyFO9Wx79LyPg.Name: Sleepstress 1.3
recNcyFO9Wx79LyPg.Bottom Body:
Your body’s energy levels and desire for sleep are driven by two key processes:
1. **Sleep Drive**
2. **Circadian alerting system** 

**Sleep Drive:** As you go about your day, your sleep drive builds and builds until finally, you get that “gee, I’m sleepy” feeling. It's due to a chemical called adenosine and sleep is the only way to reset it. 

**Circadian alerting system:** Your circadian alerting system operates by creating dips and rises throughout the day that drives sleepiness and wakefulness. It's basically a biological clock, which means it's one of your body's natural timing devices." It has its own rhythm but also gets regulated by cues in your environment.
recNcyFO9Wx79LyPg.Top Body: ## Sleep Drive vs Circadian Alerting System

recNrciZe5jFJSXv2.Name: QuickwinFA 13.2
recNrciZe5jFJSXv2.Bottom Body:
**Box Breathing!**

Did you know that anytime you feel stressed you can calm your body down nearly instantly by engaging in something called _box breathing. _It can also boost your alertness! Cool, right?

**What the heck is box breathing???**

It is a technique where you engage in deep breathing in a specific pattern.

Deep breathing activates your parasympathetic nervous system which sends signals to your body to calm down and relax quickly so you’re able to slip into a peaceful slumber!

recNua6XFjeGrVyT9.Name: mythBuster 2.2
recNua6XFjeGrVyT9.Bottom Body:
**Genetic variants**
Some people have a rare genetic mutation (called ADRB1) which reduces their sleep needs to only 4.5-6 hours of sleep a night!

**Morning person vs night owl**
There are also genes that affect how sensitive your circadian rhythm is to cues in your environment, and your body's preferred sleep schedule! More on that later. 

**The takeaway**
 In general, developing good sleep habits (with support from your friends at Rested Health) will show you how to achieve higher quality sleep. 

That means that even on nights when you get less, you can still feel Rested.

recNvr2Fu4g9MxkIx.Name: HypeUp 1.2
recNvr2Fu4g9MxkIx.Bottom Body:
As you recall, we did a little dive into Sleep Basics 101! We talked about how your:

- **Circadian rhythm** is responsible for regulating your sleep-wake cycle

- **Sleep drive** is your body’s need for sleep

- **Sleep Architecture** accounts for the quality of sleep you get and it’s made up of several stages with unique benefits

recNxDoYHOL5y3lCB.Name: QuickwinFA4.3
recNxDoYHOL5y3lCB.Bottom Body:
To avoid the dreaded "melatonin suppression" effect of regular light, try switching out your bedside lamp with a **red light bulb**!

**Wait, what?**
Unlike other forms of light that suppress melatonin (we're looking at you blue light), red light actually helps you produce more of it!

**What does that mean?**
That means using a red lightbulb in your bedside lamp won't disrupt your sleep and may even actually help you fall asleep faster!

Plus, your room will look super cool.

recO0sB3bat7JGQLl.Name: Circadian 1.2
recO0sB3bat7JGQLl.Bottom Body:
**How does my circadian rhythm work?**
Your circadian rhythm is controlled by a group of cells in your brain that sits right behind your eyes. It’s called the suprachiasmatic nucleus (say it with me, _soo-pruh-kee-uhz-ma-tuhk noo-klee-uhs_). 

Now repeat it 10 times fast! Just kidding. 

Your suprachiasmatic nucleus has a nickname– the SCN. We’ll just call it that. Your SCN takes cues from your environment to regulate your sleep-wake cycle. Why? So your body can adapt when there are changes. 

**What sort of cues are important to your circadian rhythm?**

recO8bvFd9sfW156e.Name: intake 1.18
recO8bvFd9sfW156e.Bottom Body: If yes, what do you currently use to help you sleep?

recOASNUmSqoIBMrt.Name: relearn 1.5
recOASNUmSqoIBMrt.Bottom Body:
**Knowledge is power**
These two action plans will help build the foundation of your mastery over your sleep. You won't conquer them overnight, and that's ok! 

Like we said, unlearning and relearning takes some time. There's a saying about our brains that goes:

**Neurons that fire together wire together**

**What does that mean?** It means that when we do two things at the same time, our brains connect the activities. When we don't do those things together, the strength of that connection weakens over time.

recODCeSizvw76cRX.Name: goalsleepthrunight1.4
recODCeSizvw76cRX.Bottom Body:
Mentally decompressing before bed and leaving the bed when you can't sleep are excellent tools for rebooting your relationship with sleep. 

Get started with these techniques this week and see how they help. This is just the beginning. We have plenty of advice to help you reach your goal of sleeping through the night. 

As you work through your journeys we'll keep giving you more awesome tips! Ok, back to your next journey!

recODOehZ68pPuFCh.Name: Quickwins 9.5
recODOehZ68pPuFCh.Bottom Body:
Heck yeah, they work!

Your brain loves repetition. Just like how negative thought loops lead to more negative thinking. Positive affirmations lead to more positive thinking.

They can help you feel unstuck and push you out of a rut. Even if it feels like you’re just “saying words”, over time you’ll begin to feel their impact on your well-being. 

Regular repetition of positive and affirming statements encourages your brain to take these positive affirmations as fact! It’s a fun brain hack. 

Learning to use your brain’s wiring to your advantage is a great way to crush your goals. 

Ok, let’s get back to journeys!

recOJHrkRQSyMW6bt.Name: Food 1.6
recOJHrkRQSyMW6bt.Bottom Body:
**How to avoid snack-related sleep disruptions**

Snacking wisely can help you manage your sweet (or salty) tooth without disrupting your sleep. Here are your guidelines:

1. **Choose wisely**: When you’re getting close to bedtime, select snacks that are whole foods. Make sure to include some protein because lack of protein can also impair sleep. Try your best to cut sugar during the day, or at a minimum, time it earlier in the day. 
2. **No snacks before bed**: Try your best to stop eating about 3 hours before you go to bed. At a minimum, make sure you only eat light snacks during that period. This will give your digestive system time to break down those good eats before you hit the hay.

recOdeoGsZOVgqltu.Name: Goals 1.3
recOdeoGsZOVgqltu.Bottom Body:
**SMART GOALS**
**S**pecific- Don't be vague
**M**easurable- How do you measure success?
**A**ttainable- Small and achievable
**R**elevant- Brings you closer to your big goals
**T**imely- Set time limits 

**An example, please!**
An example of a SMART goal is: “don’t hit snooze once this week.” This goal is SMART because it's very specific, definitely attainable, relevant to the overall goal to sleep better, and is timely (one week time frame). 

Let's try it out...

recOehWEKQaq6kx15.Name: intake 1.05
recOehWEKQaq6kx15.Bottom Body:
**Great work!** 

Thanks for answering all of those questions. Check-ins like this help us determine the absolute best advice you need right now! 

As your needs change, so will the advice we give you.

You know what else? All of the hard work you're putting in shows us that you're serious about improving your sleep. 

Keep it up, you're doing awesome!

recOjfMNjhcvv8nSA.Name: Quickwin 1.1
recOjfMNjhcvv8nSA.Bottom Body:
It's time for your first Quick Win! 

_Wait_, what the heck is a Quick Win again?

In case you forgot, Quick Wins will appear throughout your journeys. They are tiny habits, behaviors, or facts that help give you a boost in your journey toward better sleep!

recP6pQ4Q99IyrpK4.Name: worry 1.3
recP6pQ4Q99IyrpK4.Bottom Body:
**How does it impact sleep?**
When the subconscious mind has anxiety, it can negatively impact your programming for sleep. That anxiety ripple can even follow you into slumber, disturbing your sleep and even impacting your dreams.

It's why some people anticipate sleep problems before even getting in bed. 

It's why sometimes your head hits the pillow and you suddenly feel awake. 

It's why sometimes you wake up in the middle of the night alert and filled with thoughts and worries. 

But, we have some great news for you...

**Your mind can be reprogrammed for better sleep!**

recPAfbhNKLX9Rh64.Name: quickwinFA 5.3
recPAfbhNKLX9Rh64.Bottom Body:
Ideally, set aside 10 to 20 minutes during your nightly bedtime routine to journal. 

The purpose of journaling will be to quiet your mind, vent your thoughts, and give your brain closure on the day.  

How? There are many ways, choose what works for you. 

**You can try:**

- Writing a general "dear diary" style log about your day
- Making notes of any positive experiences you had that day
- Free association- this means setting a timer and writing absolutely anything that comes to your mind (this one can get fun)
- Creating a to-do list for tomorrow with actions (this one works really well for sleep)
- Listing all the reasons that Rested Health is your number one favorite app

**TIP:**  If you can’t solve a problem, simply write “will revisit tomorrow”– this will allow your brain to close the curtain on the item for the night.

recPJunfdNNf7rjih.Name: Quickwin 6.1
recPJunfdNNf7rjih.Bottom Body:
It’s time for your very first Reboot Camp Quick Win!

It’s a fun one, so not only will it be super easy to implement, but you’ll love making it a part of your morning routine!

Are you ready to hear your morning quick win?

recQB8h58vcsniWXP.Name: Wokeuptired 1.2
recQB8h58vcsniWXP.Bottom Body:
**1. You didn’t get enough quality sleep**

One of the more obvious reasons for not feeling Rested is because the sleep you got was lower quality. It may have felt like you slept all night, but it’s possible you spent more time in light sleep than in the more restorative deep sleep stages. 

This could be caused by problems with your sleep environment like noise, consuming alcohol or caffeine too close to bed, snoring or sleep apnea, stress, or many other reasons. 

**Fix it**
If it happens every now and then, it’s likely not a big deal and improving your sleep habits will help boost your slumber. If this happens most nights, you may want to talk to your doctor to see if there are any underlying health concerns. 

**Let’s look at other reasons you may be tired in the morning...**

recQFdTFtgNzwWR7b.Name: Supplements 1.1
recQFdTFtgNzwWR7b.Bottom Body:
So far we have learned that the things you put into your body most definitely impact your sleep. 

So, what if there was something you could put into your body that could actually directly help you sleep better?

Good news, there are a TON of sleep supplements out there that can **help improve your sleep quality**!

Say whaaaaaaaat?

recQPtX75I5DjZPzo.Name: Oriented 1.2
recQPtX75I5DjZPzo.Bottom Body:
## 1. Journey cards
Journey cards are where you'll:
- Learn the core skills you need to improve your relationships with sleep
- Tell us more about your sleep problems and goals.

### 
**WEEK 1**
**Onboarding**

You can view your first week as onboarding! We'll teach you the basics of sleep, help you understand why sleep gets so messed up, and reveal our plan for helping you reboot your relationship with sleep! 


**WEEKS 2 onwards**
**Reboot Camp and beyond**

Once you've mastered the basics, it will be time to begin your Reboot Camp. This is where you'll begin working on skills and habits that will change your relationship with sleep.

⏱**How** **long** **will** **it** **take?⏱**
- Around 4 weeks to build your foundations 
- Each week of Reboot Camp will build on your previous skills and current problems. That means, the longer you stick with us – the more mastery you build!

**TIP:** We suggest you complete journey topics at least three times a week for the best results.

recQSrOFqJx44fiY5.Name: Architecture 1.1
recQSrOFqJx44fiY5.Bottom Body:
Sleep architecture is one of the key measurements used to gauge how well you sleep. It refers to the quality of your sleep and how much time you spend in each sleep stage!

Understanding how it works can also help you understand why your sleep sometimes _feels_ better than other times. 

By learning how to optimize your sleep, you can improve your sleep architecture and gain incredible sleep benefits. 

**But, like, what is sleep architecture?**

recQT80HGzFiQIUqw.Name: Sleep Basics 101 Overview 1.4
recQT80HGzFiQIUqw.Bottom Body:
Your circadian rhythm uses its **circadian alerting system** to send you “WAKE UP” alerts throughout the day so you don’t feel sleepy too early in the day.

For every hour that you are awake, your circadian alerting system increases so you won’t fall asleep prematurely.

By the end of the day, your circadian rhythm turns off this alerting system so that your body can receive the signals from your sleep drive that it’s _finallyyyyy_ time to sleep.

recQVweou9NH7mho6.Name: wakingup 1.6
recQVweou9NH7mho6.Bottom Body:
Mastering your sleep habits will take some time. 

However, you can get started on overcoming your problems with waking up in the middle of the night feeling stressed by implementing:

1. **Journaling a to-do list before bed to mentally decompress**
2. **Leaving your bed and retreating to a relaxing hygge space if you've been awake longer than 20 minutes**

Ok, back to our regularly scheduled program (or..umm... journey)

recREjIHULqjmEzWt.Name: QuickwinFA 11.2
recREjIHULqjmEzWt.Bottom Body:
**Declutter!**

It’s common for people to underestimate the impact that a cluttered room has on sleep. 

When your brain sees clutter it interprets it as a “to-do” list and adds it to that invisible list of duties looming over your head on a daily basis. 

Activating your to-do list is a terrible idea before bedtime. 

Let’s explore some decluttering tips:

recRTHcbrXQRWrFIy.Name: Quizset 3.1
recRTHcbrXQRWrFIy.Bottom Body:
Week two of Reboot Camp is complete and it’s that time again:

**Time to flex your sleep smarts!**

This quiz will continue to consolidate your learnings and help to anchor your sleep smarts deep into your beautiful brain.

Let’s get to it, shall we? I’m so excited to see all that you learned this week!

recRXwAdPXMAlu33v.Name: Exercise 1.1
recRXwAdPXMAlu33v.Bottom Body:
**Exercise loves sleep and sleep loves exercise**

We’re sure you’ve heard before that exercise is good for you. But do you know that exercise can have an incredible effect on your sleep? Exercise is soooooo good for sleep that it’s sometimes prescribed as an alternative treatment for sleep problems. 

Even though exercise is so good for sleep, it’s sometimes hard to find accurate information about how to do it, when to do it, and how it actually helps sleep. Luckily, we’re here to help sort that out!

recRZyeQBNAUfag0s.Name: racingmind 1.2
recRZyeQBNAUfag0s.Bottom Body:
Here's the scene: You're laying in bed. Your mind is racing. You just want some peace.

**Here's what you can do:**

**Step 1:** Place a hand on your heart and feel its rhythm. Thump. Thump. Thump. 

Now, breathe in deeply through your nose for 4 seconds, then take a long, slow breath out through your mouth. 

Repeat this pattern until you can feel your heartbeat slow down. Your thoughts should soon ease up as well.

recRaKcIcdtkNrhGS.Name: Sneaky 1.1
recRaKcIcdtkNrhGS.Bottom Body:
We want to empower you to make great choices that give you the best sleep.

That's why it's important to make you aware of the sneaky sleep disruptors that commonly cause issues for people.

Let's take a look at some pesky little sleep disturbers and tips on how to avoid them...

recRfBIFIlO5k0pC3.Name: Food 1.2
recRfBIFIlO5k0pC3.Bottom Body:
**Sugary food and sleep**

Sugar tastes good, but it can really mess with your sleep. 

High levels of sugar consumed throughout your day leads to sleep disturbances and **less time in deep slow-wave sleep**. Deep sleep is incredibly important for feeling Rested. 

To complicate matters even more, your kidneys work hard to rid your body of excess sugar by sending you to pee a lot. As a result, too much sugar can also impair your sleep by repeated bathroom trips!

Excess sugar also leads to inflammation which can exacerbate pain and make it harder to maintain sleep.

But, is all sugar the same?

recRsRujiDu0G5sE7.Name: QuickwinFA 13.4
recRsRujiDu0G5sE7.Bottom Body:
Try box breathing before bed tonight to induce relaxation and fall asleep faster!

Breathing techniques are fantastic skills to have in your little toolbox.

Being able to send your body into a calmer state will also allow you to think more clearly and feel more in control.

Remember that it may be difficult at first, and that’s normal! Practicing breathing techniques will make you more efficient at breathing.

Ok, now back to our Reboot Camp journey!

recRuHAHteUOQKDxv.Name: Quiz set 1.9
recRuHAHteUOQKDxv.Bottom Body:
Wow, YOU’RE AMAZING! 

You’re just a regular ol’ sleep scientist now, with all of that sleep science info mastered!

Moving on to the rest of Reboot Camp, you’re going to be on your way to feeling SUPER RESTED in no time!

recS0oyMuoOVpiiFb.Name: Quickwin 7.4
recS0oyMuoOVpiiFb.Bottom Body:
Try cold therapy some time to see if you notice a difference in your sleep! 

As a bonus, over time you may notice that you gain many health benefits from this quick and (sort of) easy habit!

recS3VW1FJAVh7Xtq.Name: Relearn 1.1 copy
recS3VW1FJAVh7Xtq.Bottom Body:
In order to help reprogram your mind and body for better sleep, you need to reboot the association between bed and sleep.

What does that mean?
1. **Only use your bed for sleeping (and sex)**
2. **Leave the bed when you can’t sleep**

These action plans aren’t just light “suggestions”, they are the recipe you need to rebuild your relationship with sleep. They will help you improve your healthy connections and unlearn those that do not serve you.

**Let’s take a closer look at each action item...**

recS5NZUTQF5x3Qyk.Name: Waketime 1.3
recS5NZUTQF5x3Qyk.Bottom Body:
**But what if I go to bed late?**

Still get your butt out of bed at the same time! 

You may feel groggy and tired but it’s important to stick with it. Try doing an activity you really enjoy first thing in the morning. It will give you something to look forward to (we’ll give you some guidance on morning rituals in the next journey).

Maybe it’s a crossword puzzle, playing an instrument or putting on headphones and dancing to your favorite songs – just get on up!

If you’re still tired by the afternoon just grab yourself a little nap (keep it 20 minutes and before 3pm)

Want another tip that’s a game-changer?

recSDjlfTltwr3xi5.Name: Sleep Basics 101 Overview 1.2
recSDjlfTltwr3xi5.Bottom Body:
Your circadian rhythm controls your sleep-wake cycle.

Your SCN takes cues from your environment and sends the info to your circadian rhythm.

Environmental cues that affect your sleep include light, temperature, eating, and activity!

recSS8jDGk1nAMBxq.Name: caffeineSleep 1.2
recSS8jDGk1nAMBxq.Bottom Body:
**Rule # 1**
**Don't consume caffeine within the first 90 minutes of waking up.** 

**Why?** When you first wake up, your body boosts you with wakefulness-promoting chemicals. This natural process ends around 90 minutes after you've woken up. 

Drinking coffee during this window blunts the impact of caffeine. meaning you need more to get the same effect. 

**The fix?** get your caffeine hit after 90 minutes or after lunch. Both of these times are when your body will use it best!

recSkK1e95h93D7ih.Name: Noise 1.2
recSkK1e95h93D7ih.Bottom Body:
My brain can still process environmental noise when I’m asleep?

Yep. You read that right.

Not only can your brain process noise when you’re sleeping, but it leads to **less quality deep sleep**. Not good. Not good at all. 

Studies have found that noise pollution during sleep causes disturbances that lead to subjective distress. We’re talking – daytime sleepiness, decreased well-being, lower cognitive performance, mood changes, and it can even exacerbate or contribute to mental illness!

You still hear and process sounds while you sleep, even if you don’t recall being disturbed. 

So, let’s talk about how to eliminate environmental noise so it doesn’t interrupt your slumber...

recTMJQ6cJtknAti6.Name: Overview 1.2
recTMJQ6cJtknAti6.Bottom Body:
**Build a strong foundation for change**

Building a strong foundation takes time, consistency, and resilience.

Improving your sleep will require you to build a foundation of:

- Basic fundamental sleep knowledge
- Good habits
- Quick wins
- SMART goals 

Once you have a strong foundation of good habits you can begin to add more advanced stuff without feeling overwhelmed. 

Keeping it simple at the beginning is a key to success!

recTZjDR6K7rLB2J8.Name: habittips 1.4
recTZjDR6K7rLB2J8.Bottom Body:
**4. TALK TO YOURSELF**

Nobody knows you better than yourself. If you're having trouble implementing changes or find that you're feeling stuck – explore why! 

Ask yourself – **"what is holding me back?"** 

Sometimes you may need to remove hurdles or break your goals into even smaller tasks that help you get unstuck. 

Whatever the case, having honest discussions with yourself will help you continue to grow and help you overcome obstacles. 

**We got you**
You can also talk to your sleep coach who can help give insight into some issues you might be facing. Life happens, we are here to make sure that no matter what some your way – it doesn't derail you.

recTcTkOUwqOZmIes.Name: Overview 2.5
recTcTkOUwqOZmIes.Bottom Body:
**How to track your sleep**

**Wearables** have cool features that give you interesting information about your sleep. The data from your tracker get analyzed and put into graphs that help you get an idea of your sleep.

There are a bunch of fun options: wrist wearables, finger wearables, and head wearables, and even some that you don’t wear at all. 

Or, another alternative is to keep a **sleep diary.**

A sleep diary is helpful because it captures things that a wearable can’t, such as your emotions or what you ate.

You can download a sleep diary app, download a template online, or simply make notes in a journal. Include any and all sleep-related info and try to use it for at least 2 weeks.

Use whatever option you enjoy the most to track your sleep progress!

recU9dujoBhJFLHxF.Name: Architecture 1.3
recU9dujoBhJFLHxF.Bottom Body:
One of the most effective ways of optimizing sleep is by doing aerobic exercise during the day. **Doing at least 20 minutes of cardiovascular activity** like swimming or jogging has been shown to significantly increase the amount of time you spend in restorative deep sleep. 

Deep sleep is when your growth hormone levels peak. This makes your skin glow, builds muscle, burns fat, and more.

Growth hormone levels decrease with age, which means the amount we get during sleep becomes increasingly important and beneficial.  

Cool, right?

recUKFtgVImRPKKZP.Name: HypeUp 1.4
recUKFtgVImRPKKZP.Bottom Body:
These were your first building blocks to build a **strong foundation** that will reboot your sleep. 

As you begin to practice these habits, you’ll continue to move up the competency ladder and toward habit mastery!

Always remember – building a strong foundation takes **time, consistency, and resilience.**

So, keeping your changes small, your goals SMART, and your self-talk positive will keep you on the path toward better sleep.

recUKOuvHbFlopBh3.Name: Food 1.8
recUKOuvHbFlopBh3.Bottom Body:
So the takeaway for today’s Reboot Camp is:

1. Snacks can disrupt your sleep
2. Avoid snacking 3 hours before bed if you can. If you absolutely must eat, pick something light and balanced (a little protein, carbohydrates, and fat).

Now we’ve covered food, but what about drinks?

Journey on to learn about hydration!

recUKr9NZlzpiVjoF.Name: Circadian 1.7
recUKr9NZlzpiVjoF.Bottom Body:
**Activity**
Physical activity is a strong cue for your circadian rhythm. The time of day you exercise can have a direct impact on your circadian rhythm. Exercise can even be used to adjust your circadian rhythm forwards or backward. 

For instance, people who fall asleep too early can use evening physical activity to push their circadian rhythm later! Cool, right?

recUM0BSAJdbXKmaK.Name: Quickwin 12.2
recUM0BSAJdbXKmaK.Bottom Body:
**Tryptophan**
Your body uses this amino acid to make serotonin and melatonin. Both chemicals are important to sleep.

Have you heard of turkey comas? That sleep thanksgiving snoozy feeling is due to the high amounts of tryptophan in turkey! (ok it might also be related to the 12 lbs of mashed potatoes and 3 slices of pie you ate)

**Sleep-inducing snacks and the amount of tryptophan per serving:**

- Whole Milk (211mg)
- Turkey (687 mg)
- Salmon (203 mg)
- Soy beans (a.k.a. edamame) (416 mg)
- Pumpkin seeds (164 mg)
- Oatmeal (94 mg)

recUZJlAg2NTlDUKr.Name: Decompression 1.6
recUZJlAg2NTlDUKr.Bottom Body:
**Are you sure about this bedtime routine thing?**
It may feel bizarre at first to implement a bedtime routine, but it can really change your life. Especially if you have a busy mind before bed.  

It’s true that new habits can be hard to stick with. The point is always: _progress not perfection. So,_ try not to get discouraged if things don’t always go as planned. Change takes time.

It usually takes about four weeks for a new habit to feel automatic, so be patient with yourself. After that point, it takes much less mental energy to engage in your new behaviors (remember that unconsciously competent thing?)

This is why it's fine (and even encouraged) to take your time and slowly add new things to your bedtime routine.

recUanOZQjpXawKEK.Name: BasicsQ 1.9
recUanOZQjpXawKEK.Bottom Body:
Ok, wow, we only have 3 left. Look at you go! Your dedication to completing these quizzes is awesome. 

The next section in your journeys was all about "Fall asleep faster".

You remember this one, right? Let's go get'em...

recUfDJslKQ1tCPM8.Name: Science 1.3
recUfDJslKQ1tCPM8.Bottom Body:
During the night you move through several stages of sleep. These stages each have specific benefits and unique qualities. Your sleep architecture is your pattern of sleep stages across the night (it looks like a city skyline).

There are two types of sleep: 
1. **Rapid-eye-movement sleep (REM)**
2. **Non-rapid-eye-movement sleep (NREM)**: which includes stages N1, N2, and N3. 

REM sleep is primarily when you dream, you spend more time in REM during the second half of the night. 

As for NREM stages, N1 and N2 include lighter sleep while N3 includes deep restorative sleep. 

Each stage is very important and impacts your daily health and functioning in unique ways. 

We'll learn more about sleep stages later. 

Improving your sleep architecture means improving the **quality** of your sleep. Let's look at a quick tip on how to optimize sleep architecture!

recUfPeI1GMxirfSB.Name: Goals 1.2
recUfPeI1GMxirfSB.Bottom Body:
Knowing your own goals is important. 

**The road to big goals**
On the road to reaching that goal, you'll need to set many other smaller goals in order to get there.

Smaller goals are vital because they:
- Increase your chances of success
- Boost morale (i.e. "yay, I achieved a thing!")
- Bring you closer to your big goals!

In order to set you up for success, we want you to make **SMART** goals. 

**Wait, what's a SMART goal?**

recUzrst0LBnKCTnb.Name: QuickwinFA2.4
recUzrst0LBnKCTnb.Bottom Body:
**Making Lists**
Laying in bed struggling with a busy mind sucks. To use this technique you don't even have to move. 

**To begin:** Lay there with your eyes closed and relax your jaw (you'll be surprised how much tension lives in there).

Next, you'll begin making lists! The first grounding technique for sleep that we want to share with you is listing random objects.

**Listing random objects:**  It's as simple as that. Start naming random things in your head and keep going.

For example: "Potato, car, pen, jeans, notepad, etc."

This technique will pull you out of any unhelpful thought loops and allow your mind to find peace. It's an extremely effective and easy-to-use tool that many people find helpful for sleep. 

ok, back to journeys!

recVEhlKB9B1Ezxz9.Name: Quiz Set 2.1
recVEhlKB9B1Ezxz9.Bottom Body:
Week one of Reboot Camp is DOWN and it’s time to flex your sleep smarts!

These quizzes are meant to help consolidate your learnings. 

We want to make sure that all of these great tips get anchored in that lovely brain of yours.

Having these amazing sleep tips in your back pocket will make it that much easier to start sleeping better and feeling more Rested!

You have officially begun rebooting your mind this week, now tell us what you learned!!

recVJQJMUskyYd352.Name: mythBuster 1.3
recVJQJMUskyYd352.Bottom Body:
**As a rule, the number of dreams you can recall is _not_ an indication of your sleep quality!!**

When you wake up they are gone with the wind. Out the door. Adios. Byyyyyyeeeeee. 

**That's why dreams are never a good way to rate your quality of sleep!**

Isn't myth busting fun? 

We've gathered a ton of cool sleep facts, research, and little "wow" moments that we'll keep sharing with you. 

You'll become the "sleep person" in your friend group in no time!

recVLHYrN9FlRDFGR.Name: Electronics 1.8
recVLHYrN9FlRDFGR.Bottom Body:
**Blue light blocking programs**: 
You can install programs on your computer (i.e f.lux) that automatically adjust the color and brightness of your screen based on your timezone. 

As it gets dark outside, the program gives your monitor an orange hue by blocking blue light. There are similar apps available for smartphones, and some phones have a built-in “night-mode”. Use it!

**Blue light blocking glasses**: 
You can buy a pair of amber-tinted blue light blocking lenses. The clearer lenses block 30% of blue light, while amber or brown tinted lenses block up to 100% of blue light! 

**Level-up**
These tips won't take away all of the sleep issues that devices cause, but they will reduce the impact of blue light on your sleep. If you really want to optimize your sleep, you'll want to take steps to remove electronics 2 hours before sleep time.

recVaUUugPreaSZN8.Name: wakingup 1.4
recVaUUugPreaSZN8.Bottom Body:
**2. Hygge space** 

Here's the scene: You wake up in the middle of the night. You toss and turn and want nothing more than to fall back asleep. Sleep isn't coming. 

Remaining in your bed for longer than 20 minutes during these sleepless nights can make the issue worse. Your brain creates associations between the stress you feel and your bed. 

**So what now?** The absolute best practice is to leave your bed and retreat somewhere relaxing. But where? Your hygge space!

recVdsOQcwsfvSsOU.Name: Quickwin 1.2
recVdsOQcwsfvSsOU.Bottom Body:
You can easily implement quick wins into your daily routine to help you sleep better, fall asleep faster, or just feel better. 

So, are you ready for your first ever quick win?

recVfZZOwvhFkpSJc.Name: Grogginess 1.3
recVfZZOwvhFkpSJc.Bottom Body:
**Fake it ‘til you make it.**

This is our number one tip for when you wake up tired. It sounds simple, but it actually works! This is another one of those brain hacks.

Just like how smiling when you’re in a foul mood will lift your spirits, acting awake and ok when you’re feeling low energy can actually help boost your energy levels.

A thought is just a thought. You have control over your thoughts! When you wake up tired try thinking “I feel good, I feel energized, I’m going to have a good day.”

Creating these positive thoughts in your brain and keeping busy as you go about your day will do wonders to save a low energy day!

But what if faking it isn’t doing the trick?

recVqZaS4ZRK2UeNc.Name: QuickwinFA 12.2
recVqZaS4ZRK2UeNc.Bottom Body:
**Melatonin**
Previously it was believed that you could only find melatonin in animals’s pineal glands. It is now well known that melatonin also naturally occurs in certain plants, fungi, insects and bacteria (bacteria and insect sandwich, anyone?)

Your body uses melatonin to regulate your circadian rhythm and keep you snoozing at night. Research has shown that eating foods containing melatonin can enhance your body’s natural production. 

When it comes to melatonin, you only need a little. Research has shown that taking 0.3 mg is more effective for improving sleep than higher doses. That’s because it better imitates your body’s natural levels.

**Let’s look at some melatonin-rich snacks!**

recVuIWC6GKBvJafV.Name: habittips 1.3
recVuIWC6GKBvJafV.Bottom Body:
**3. PLAN TO FAIL**

Nobody just changes overnight. It takes time, it involves ups and downs, and sometimes you feel like you're going backwards. The important thing is to get back on track.

Acknowledging that change involves failure is vital to success. One great piece of advice is "never miss twice." That is to say, don't skip anything twice in a row. If you missed making your bed once, don't miss it twice. 

Failure is an option! Learn from it and move forward.

recVxzwnNWopbA66k.Name: Hydration 1.5
recVxzwnNWopbA66k.Bottom Body:
**Yes! It is possible to hydrate your way to a better sleep!**

Here are our basic tips to help:

- **Choose water**: Avoid drinking too much caffeine, alcohol, or sugary beverages as they are known to cause sleep disturbances. Choose clean tap water, filtered water, or one of many delicious sparkling waters on the market. 

- **Balance your diet**: Fruits and vegetables have a high moisture content which can increase your water intake. Watermelon, for example, is 92% water. So, eat your fruits and veggies!

recVzfklEVayW2Obz.Name: spower 1.6
recVzfklEVayW2Obz.Bottom Body:
**Your mood on sleep**
If you've ever missed out on some sleep, it's likely no surprise to hear that sleep helps your mood. **But how?**

**Sleep actually improves your ability to handle stress!**

**Sleep:**
- Increases your patience
- Regulates your stress response
- Makes more space for logical thoughts
- Cools your temper and irritability

**Your world on sleep**
Getting adequate sleep boosts happiness and helps us meet the best version of ourselves. It enriches our inner lives and makes the world around us kinder and easier to navigate. 

Cool, right? Now, let's see all of the benefits good sleep has for our bodies!

recW1a1YisT1441Zj.Name: Overview 2.1
recW1a1YisT1441Zj.Bottom Body:
Wow! Can you believe that 2 weeks of Reboot Camp went by so quickly?! 

Don’t be sad, because we’re not even close to being done with you yet!! 

But before we move on, let’s recap all of the greatness you acquired this past week!

In week 2 of Reboot Camp you learned about:

- **Why and how to build a sleep sanctuary**
- **How your brain processes your sleep environment **

Let us quickly go over what you learned about each!

recW75giRMuLOn4Ut.Name: Tracking 1.01
recW75giRMuLOn4Ut.Bottom Body:
**Alternatives that you don’t have to wear**

Sometimes you don't want to wear anything to bed, and that's ok!

Bedside devices are available that use data such as your breathing patterns and movement to analyze your sleep. 

They gather data using motion sensors, radio waves (similar to echolocation), and sound. 

**Popular alternative sleep monitors** 
- **Bedside** (SleepScore Max, ResMed S+)
- **Under mattress** (Beddit, Withings Sleep, Nokia) 
- **Smart Pillow** (iSense, ZEEQ)

**Pros:** You don’t have to wear anything and they provide useful information.

recWGZiZxpjeQ6wgZ.Name: Mornings 1.5
recWGZiZxpjeQ6wgZ.Bottom Body:
Hydrating yourself is the most refreshing way to start your day, and it’s so healthy for your body too!

It might even make you feel like a health guru. “Look at me drinking water first thing in the morning, like some sort of health guru” you might say.

As a tip, if you’re not into drinking plain water, try adding a slice of lemon or some berries for a little pizazz! 

Ok, let’s look at the next tip that you can use to build out an amazing basic morning ritual...

recWJRtbDmkRBwaaH.Name: BedtimeBasics 1.9
recWJRtbDmkRBwaaH.Bottom Body:
So there you have it, you know have the most basic of the bedtime basics in your back pocket. 

Just to quickly recap:

1. **Buy moisture-wicking sheets**
2. **Set the temperature to COOL (65℉ (18.3℃).**

By combining what you’ve learned here today, you’re well on your way to creating the sleep sanctuary of your dreams.

recWWkU7iCXkVOUbh.Name: Wokeuptired 1.3
recWWkU7iCXkVOUbh.Bottom Body:
**2. You woke up on the wrong side of the sleep cycle**

During the night you go through several 90 minute sleep cycles. If your alarm goes off while you are in deep sleep you may experience **sleep inertia**.

Sleep inertia is temporary but can be pretty intense. It makes you feel groggy, disoriented, and stuck between sleep and wakefulness. 

Most people feel better within 15-30 minutes but it can take hours to actually feel awake. It can happen when you’re abruptly awakened from any stage, but is much worse if awoken from slow wave deep sleep or REM. 

**Fix it**
You can solve this issue by getting a smart alarm that wakes your up when your sleep is lighter. You can also calculate your ideal sleep schedule so that you wake up at the end of a sleep cycle 

**Get your ideal sleep time**
- The average sleep cycle is 90 minutes long and you should get around 5 full sleep cycles a night. 
- 90 x 5 = 450 minutes, or 7.5 hours
- Starting at your wake time, work back 7.5 hours to find your ideal bedtime!

recWXH8Gn5zblwHxO.Name: QuickwinFA 8.4
recWXH8Gn5zblwHxO.Bottom Body:
Grounding techniques are great ways to distract your mind so that your body can more easily slip into slumber. Exiting stressful thought loops allows your body to find calm.

You can combine deep breathing with grounding techniques for even more relaxation!

recWidU3a706qeBFs.Name: Electronics 1.4
recWidU3a706qeBFs.Bottom Body:
**Blue light is everywhere!**
Blue light from the sun isn’t the only source of blue light in your life. 

You also get blue light from artificial sources such as:

- Television screens
- Digital devices (phones, tablets, computer monitors)
- Fluorescent lights
- LED lights

**Is blue light always bad?**
When used correctly (i.e. during the daytime), blue light can help you focus, boost energy, and even help regulate your sleep-wake cycle. 

However, most of us are getting way too much, especially late in the evenings.

Let’s take a look at why that’s a problem...

recWvO0e84QzV3KGi.Name: Quickwin 6.3
recWvO0e84QzV3KGi.Bottom Body:
So, consider starting your day with a sweet jam and dance sesh and see how awesome you feel after!

You might even feel ready to conquer the world!

Now, let’s get back to Reboot Camp! First we conquer sleep, then we conquer the world. Muahahaha!

recWzFSpjgGpbPlms.Name: habittips 1.5
recWzFSpjgGpbPlms.Bottom Body:
At the end of the day, the most important tip is to believe in yourself. 

The term is called **self-efficacy**. 

Self-efficacy means believing that you can do it and being resilient in the face of challenges. 

That means in those moments where you feel overwhelmed, exhausted, and stuck...

You look in the mirror and say "you can do this"

Because you **can** do this! You can gain mastery over your sleep. You can change the habits that don't serve you. You can conquer the challenges and revel in the victories. 

You can do it!!

recX4KqU74YTQzUkC.Name: Why  1.5
recX4KqU74YTQzUkC.Bottom Body:
**Let's look at the psychology of it all**
According to Maslow's hierarchy of needs, in order to reach the best versions of ourselves, we need to have our basic needs met. 

**The foundation**
The foundation of this model is our physiological needs. Things like food, shelter, breathing, and **sleep**. 

If we constantly struggle with sleep, it can make us feel stuck at the bottom. We might even obsess over it.

That's one of the reasons that sleep issues can feel like a dark cloud that's hovering above you.

recXDpyAdaSZjkO2G.Name: relearn 1.6
recXDpyAdaSZjkO2G.Bottom Body:
**Reboot and rebuild the smart way**
Many of the habits we have that aren't helpful to sleep also bring us comfort, so getting rid of them can be tricky. Fortunately, you'll learn the most effective tips for change through this app! (so clever of you to join us)

**We got your back**
We'll keep reminding you and continually give you tips for success. For now, just focus on the fact that your bed should be restricted to sleep and sex only and that learning by association is a very real thing.

**Get started**
Start out by eliminating one unhelpful activity three nights this week. You don't have to change everything overnight! It's all about progress, not perfection.

recXGSlRAkGdjCgFf.Name: Trackingprogress 1.3
recXGSlRAkGdjCgFf.Bottom Body:
**Other ways to track**
Sleep diaries aren't the only way to track your sleep. 

There are now many wearable health and fitness trackers that also have sleep tracking built-in!

You can find them for your wrist, finger, head, or even beside your bed. 

These trackers measure things like heart rate, activity, and even brainwaves to measure the quality and length of your sleep.

**Are they accurate?**
Wearables do a pretty good job of tracking total sleep time. They aren't the most accurate when it comes to sleep stages, so don't rely on that information to guide too many decisions about what's working.

recXpw7wT3JEJrcW5.Name: QuickWinFA 10.3
recXpw7wT3JEJrcW5.Bottom Body:
There are a couple of ways to try this method, one of the more popular ways is to turn the tables on your inability to sleep!

**How? **Take every opportunity to be carefree about your inability to fall asleep. 
- Accept that you have trouble sleeping and indulge in opportunities to leave bed when you can
- Try to imagine all of the catastrophes that your brain creates over lack of sleep and notice how absurd they are. Pretend you are on a debate stage and break down your thoughts in a logical way!
- Take the time you are awake to do something useful that you enjoy

recXq4aLgmYWVe6yi.Name: Food 1.4
recXq4aLgmYWVe6yi.Bottom Body:
**High-fat food and sleep**

High-fat foods may cause you to have a **fragmented sleep** at night.

Researchers have found that high-fat foods can decrease sensitivity to the brain chemical, orexin, which is helpful in maintaining the body’s sleep and wakefulness. 

A high-fat diet may also lead to disruptions of sleep signals by delaying a sleep protein called elF2a. 

Overall, research consistently shows that a high-fat diet is associated with shorter sleep times. It’s especially worse when it’s a high fat, low protein, high sugar diet (sorry to come for potato chips and cookies like that).

**What about a keto diet?**

Things are a little more complicated with a keto diet. The shift in your energy needs with this diet generally causes changes to your sleep needs. If this is a topic you’d like to learn more about, reach out to your sleep coach for more info!
 
We aren’t done though, there’s another type of food that impacts sleep...

recY4mm1OeK9hasOl.Name: models 1.7
recY4mm1OeK9hasOl.Top Body:
**Awesome!** 

Building new habits can be hard. We want you to succeed! We want you to sleep better! We want you to feel better! 

That means we're here to support you and help you move up that ladder. 

So, let's just drop everything and start at the bottom of the ladder together. We'll build out a program that will help you gain mastery over **your** sleep.

recY6UOuBGjwmYLdo.Name: goalfallasleepfaster1.4
recY6UOuBGjwmYLdo.Bottom Body:
**Did that sound familiar?** When you have trouble falling asleep, lying in bed and wrestling with sleep only creates subconscious sleep stress. 

The more you do it, the more your mind anticipates stressing over sleep.

**The fix?** Only go to bed when you are tired.

**What if I don't get tired?** Your body will eventually succumb to sleep. While you're waiting for sleep, do a relaxing activity in a dimly lit room.

**But, I'll be tired the next day!** Yes, this is possible. However, in order to reboot your sleep, it means you may have to have some sleep disruptions at first. 

**Do I still have to wake up at the same time if I stayed up late?** Yes! But make sure you are able to move your schedule around if you're extremely sleep-deprived. 

This technique will also help to regulate the physiological processes that drive sleep (more about that later).

recYC6JRGMN9zL7zx.Name: irrationalThoughts 1.5
recYC6JRGMN9zL7zx.Bottom Body:
**It feels silly but it works**
It may feel silly at first to break down your own thinking, but it's a skill that will continually offer you benefits in every area of your life. 

Try to identify one exaggerated or irrational thought today and use this technique to reframe it! Over time, you'll find that your sleep stress will be reduced as your thoughts get met with more logic. 

ok, back to our regularly scheduled journeys!

recYTiBEq8UUwVnoC.Name: HypeUp 1.6
recYTiBEq8UUwVnoC.Bottom Body:
Once again, you may have already seen some of these techniques, while others will be new to you. Keep an open mind! You are building tools that will make your mindset stronger and your habits easier to stick with. 

That means, just because it didn’t work in the past, doesn’t mean it won't work for you now! Like we said, finding out what works takes trial and error and we’re here to support you every step along the way.

Cool? Cool. 

OK, let’s dive into your next week of Reboot Camp!

recYVEfXiPyWYxIgC.Name: Quickwin 1.5
recYVEfXiPyWYxIgC.Bottom Body:
Try grabbing a warm bath or shower around 1-2 hours before your desired bedtime. Stay in there at least 10 minutes (you can stay longer if you want, we don't pay your water bill) and notice how much it helps you sleep!

That's it for today's Quick Win. But, don't worry, we have many more of these sweet little tidbits coming your way! 

Ok, back to journeys (you can take a break now if you like, we officially give you permission).

recYWoTXM4KvWXxZE.Name: QuickWinFA 10.1
recYWoTXM4KvWXxZE.Bottom Body:
iiiiiiiiiiiiiiit's Quick Win time! 

Today we want to give you another tip that can help you fall asleep faster. 

**Why are we giving you so many tips for this?** Because we want you to find what works for you. Having various tools to deal with stress and unwanted wakefulness can help you feel more confident in your ability to manage the discomfort of being unable to fall asleep. 

Let's check out today's tip!

recYYYy0utPWfin40.Name: irrationalThoughts 1.4
recYYYy0utPWfin40.Bottom Body:
**Reducing stressful thoughts**
You can use this technique with any thought that brings you stress. The more you practice the better you'll get!

To get started, try writing out your unhelpful or stress-inducing thought in a notebook. Pretend you are an external critic and write out arguments for and against your thought. Then proceed to reframe the thought in a way that honors the evidence you've presented! 

Over time, you'll develop the skills to better manage these types of thoughts as they come.

**A thought on thoughts**
Remember, a thought is just a thought. You always have more control over your thoughts than you realize. 

Learning to find that space between a thought and a reaction takes some time, but it will empower you to find logic when your mind is leaning into dramatics.

recYlCdoadOtGmChr.Name: QuickwinFA 14.2
recYlCdoadOtGmChr.Bottom Body:
If you are being woken up during a deep sleep stage, you’re likely going to feel groggy.

By waking up during a lighter stage of sleep, you’re probably going to find yourself feeling more refreshed and alert.

**Smart alarms have entered the chat!**

What is a smart alarm?

recYoIwZQ1m4ipK8L.Name: Waketime 1.4
recYoIwZQ1m4ipK8L.Bottom Body:
**Don’t hit snooze**

We’ll repeat this one a lot because it’s important– DO NOT HIT SNOOZE IN THE MORNING! 

We want you to learn how to work with your body’s natural rhythms and snoozing in the morning is very disruptive to your natural biological processes. It can leave you extra sleepy, disoriented, and make it harder to start the day. 

Learn what you can do instead of pressing snooze...

recZ1pczLW6TKv6MI.Name: unlearn 1.4
recZ1pczLW6TKv6MI.Bottom Body:
**Other links**
When you do things in your bed and bedroom that aren't sleep or sex, your bed and bedroom become linked with feelings of stress, worry, alertness, and frustration. 

As you can imagine, these aren’t exactly helpful programs for sleep. 

**Some examples include:**
- **Watching TV in bed**
- **Working from bed**
- **Scrolling your phone in bed (morning or night)**
- **Eating in bed**

Ok, so how do you reprogram?

recZ5NwTgttsHxiSR.Name: Electronics 1.7
recZ5NwTgttsHxiSR.Bottom Body:
**Unplug, unplug, unplug!**

Do you best to reduce your screen time during the day. In the evening, you should aim to put your electronics completely away at least 2 hours before bed. 

It can be hard to make these changes right away, especially if your current bedtime routine includes watching tv or scrolling your phone (we know change is no fun, especially when we’re coming for your electronics!)

If you must use electronics in the evening, you can minimize the impact of blue light with the next two tips.

recZBkXHLHRoRRwio.Name: Bedroom 1.2
recZBkXHLHRoRRwio.Bottom Body:
**Don’t see the light**

You know all about how your body naturally produces melatonin when the sun goes down, so this next tip shouldn’t come as a surprise to you!

A sleep sanctuary needs **DARKNESS**

Sleeping in a dark environment is going to give you a better quality sleep by allowing continuous melatonin production through the night!

Even though it’s generally dark at bedtime (unless you’re a shift worker), the majority of people have a lot of light pollution in their rooms. Whether it’s digital devices, outdoor lights, or even a fish tank, there’s light and it’s interfering with your sleep!

We have some things you can do that will help you bathe in darkness.

recZCmrJcBF22NkZ2.Name: Tracking 1.6
recZCmrJcBF22NkZ2.Bottom Body:
**Choices, choices, choices...**
Since you are so interested in better sleep, we'd like to show you all of the options you have for wearables!

Many people don't even realize that there are many options out there for tracking sleep!! 

Let's take a look at the different kinds of wearables, maybe you'll find something super spectacularly awesome for you!

recZDjVs5sIO4zA8l.Name: models  1.2
recZDjVs5sIO4zA8l.Bottom Body:
Psychiatrist Milton Erickson developed this model of learning and skill development. It applies to pretty much every skill you've ever started, worked on, or mastered!

As you learn a new skill or habit, you travel through 4 stages of competence. 

**1. Unconsciously incompetent**: "I don't realize I have a problem, so I don't know I need to fix it"

**2. Consciously incompetent:** "I know I have a problem, but I don't know how to fix it"

**3. Consciously competent:** "I know how how to fix my problem, but it takes a lot of energy to implement the habits" 

**4. Unconsciously competent:** "I know how to fix my problem, and I've been practicing a lot, so my habits feel automatic"

The competence ladder shows us the steps we need to take to master a new habit. 

**Started from the bottom**
With this ladder, it's important to spend time at each rung. Yes! Even the bottom! 

**Now we're here**
Think of it as a ladder we'll slowly climb together.

Let's look at each rung on the ladder...

recZgEWJUY2SB0Vce.Name: relearn 1.2
recZgEWJUY2SB0Vce.Bottom Body:
In order to weaken the associations between nonsleep activities and bed AND to strengthen the association between bed and sleep – there are two key action items we'll ask you to do!

**Key action items to reboot your relationship with sleep:**
1. **Only use your bed for sleeping (and sex**)
2. **Leave the bed when you can’t sleep**

These action plans aren’t just light “suggestions”, they are the recipe you need to begin rebuilding your relationship with sleep. 

They will help you improve your healthy connections and unlearn those that do not serve you. 

Let’s take a closer look at each action item...

recZlZvJxMeRCluHq.Name: Sleepdrive 1.1
recZlZvJxMeRCluHq.Bottom Body:
Your sleep drive is responsible for your body’s road to slumberville. It is your body’s **need for sleep.**

**How does it work?** There is a chemical in your brain called _adenosine_ that is constantly building while you are awake (yep, like _right now!_).

After about 16 hours of being awake, the built-up adenosine creates an unbearable **sleep pressure** that tells you it’s time to go to bed. 

It’s one of the reasons you start feeling tired at the end of the day!

_So, what exactly is adenosine?_

recZoGRL7kbL93kLj.Name: Quickwin 14.1
recZoGRL7kbL93kLj.Bottom Body:
Surprise! You didn’t think we’d end this week of Reboot Camp without a final quick win, now did ya??!

Not a chance. We want to make sure that you have as many quick wins in your sleep toolbox as possible.

So here’s the next one!

recZqtkNGqvZzzjtX.Name: caffeineSleep 1.5
recZqtkNGqvZzzjtX.Bottom Body:
**Helpful tip**
**Stack caffeine with L-Theanine**

To help reduce your caffeine intake and also ease those caffeine jitters, try taking your coffee with an amino acid called L-Theanine. 

L-theanine is naturally found in tea leaves. On its own, it improves focus and reduces stress. 

Taking a dose of 50 mg of L-Theanine with 100 mg of caffeine can significantly improve attention and cognitive performance, better than just coffee alone. 

This powerful little supplement is easy to take and boosts coffee’s good effects while reducing your stress response.

recZw6VdHxoM3rW3f.Name: racingmind 1.1
recZw6VdHxoM3rW3f.Bottom Body:
A racing mind at night is one of the most common reasons people have trouble falling asleep. In your journeys, we'll teach you how to build a routine that decreases your end-of-day stress.

But how about a quick fix for when it happens? We got you. 

There are many different techniques you can use, with some trial and error, you can definitely learn how to tame a busy mind before bed. 

Let's take a look...

reca4P454GYUJ6ZMw.Name: quickwinFA 3.2
reca4P454GYUJ6ZMw.Bottom Body:
**Habit-stacking**

You may or may not have heard of habit-stacking. Either way, it's important to understand how you can use this concept to help you build new habits around sleep!

**What is habit-stacking**
Building new habits is hard and mentally taxing. One excellent technique that makes building new habits WAY easier is habit-stacking. 

You take your new habit that you want to build and you combine it with a habit you already have! For instance, if you want to add diaphragmatic breathing to your day – combine it with your morning cup of coffee (but, like, not while there's coffee in your mouth).

reca9rfnZXuVv4TV6.Name: Tracking 2.2
reca9rfnZXuVv4TV6.Bottom Body:
**What should you track in a sleep diary?**
Sleep diaries are meant to give helpful information and insights into what affects your sleep. It's ok if everything is not 100% accurate.

**What to track in your sleep diary:**
1. **Sleep and wake times** 
2. **Awakenings during the night and why**
3. **Notes on any difficulties falling back asleep**
4. **Medications or drugs used that day**
5. **Naps during the day**
6. **Extras**- general mood, caffeine and alcohol consumption, time of last meal, exercise, and whether you completed your morning or evening rituals. 

Athletes and people seeking peak performance might get extremely specific with noting factors like meal timing, fasting schedule, types of workout, and supplements used. 

For now, just keep it simple!

Why bother with a sleep diary, though?

recaDsp5y3GA0vzjy.Name: change 1.7
recaDsp5y3GA0vzjy.Bottom Body:
It's normal to feel stuck. 

It's also normal to struggle when trying to make changes. 

We want you to succeed and we'll help you every step along the way! 

**So, as we begin this journey together we ask you to:**
- Put on your "fresh start" hat (you'll gain more from the program if you approach it with an open mind)
- Set achievable goals – tiny daily changes!
- Stick with it – consistency over motivation
- Track your progress and lean into your support systems

Now let's climb that competence ladder together and crush some goals!!!

recajHN7FMji0rGcC.Name: Substances 1.5
recajHN7FMji0rGcC.Bottom Body:
**The friend that won't leave**
Because it takes your body so long to metabolize caffeine, if you consume it later in the day it can: 
- make it harder to fall asleep 
- reduce the quality of your sleep

To make things even trickier, caffeine can be really sneaky! You can find it in snacks, sodas, and even in some over-the-counter medications!

**How to avoid caffeine problems**
So, to avoid the impact of caffeine on sleep, follow these rules:
1. No caffeine after 2pm
2. Try and stick with around 400mg a day (~2-3 cups of coffee)
3. Watch out for sneaky caffeine in things like headache medicine, pre-workout, chocolate, and sodas!

OK, that wasn’t so bad, right? Let’s move on to alcohol and sleep...

recbDeYFuw1BYhqLr.Name: Mornings 1.2
recbDeYFuw1BYhqLr.Bottom Body:
Morning rituals can truly change your life. Here are a few benefits:

1. They help set your day off in a positive tone
2. They are happiness boosting
3. They help you sleep better at night

Your morning ritual doesn’t have to be elaborate or time-consuming. It’s actually pretty important that you look forward to doing it (otherwise it will feel like a chore). 

Understanding how morning rituals can improve your life is also important because we’re more likely to do things when we know why they benefit us!

recbfJWaKP3izkNQL.Name: Needs 1.5
recbfJWaKP3izkNQL.Bottom Body:
Now, that we've agreed upon realistic sleep needs, let's explore a little bit more about your relationship with sleep.

**Spoiler alert:** It's complicated.

recbnTDhAGi1rs1gd.Name: Quickwin 7.2
recbnTDhAGi1rs1gd.Bottom Body:
Cold water therapy has been making waves for quite a while now. It can boost immune functioning, ease muscle soreness, and can even help decrease symptoms of depression. 

More research needs to be done on all of the health-bosting benefits, but as for now, millions of people around the world swear by cold therapy!

**What about sleep?** Another helpful benefit of cold water is that it lowers your body temperature. This can help you fall asleep faster and get deeper sleep.

Let’s look at how to do it!

recc0RNdNXhyF9JZR.Name: Grogginess 1.7
recc0RNdNXhyF9JZR.Bottom Body:
We know you’ll likely turn to caffeine when you’re tired, so here’s how to make your caffeine work better for you:

**Caffeine hack**
Wait until 90 minutes after your wake up time to drink your coffee. That’s when your “wakefulness” hormones start to decline and your body will best use the caffeine. 

Next, take L-Theanine with your coffee. Taking a dose of 50 mg of L-Theanine with 100 mg of caffeine can significantly improve attention and cognitive performance, better than just coffee alone! As a bonus, it also reduces your body’s stress response.

That means no caffeine jitters (they’re always worse when you’re tired, aren’t they?)

reccM4MkRS8rifeX2.Name: Quiz set 1.1
reccM4MkRS8rifeX2.Bottom Body:
Are you ready for your very first Reboot Camp quiz?!?!?!

This is your chance to show us all you have learned so far, and we can’t wait to see it!

So far, you’ve learned the sleep basics, the basic science of sleep, the spaghetti sauce of sleep, if you will. 

Now show us how you can kick this quiz to knowledge town! Is that a saying? That's definitely not a saying. 

umm LET'S JUST DO THE QUIZ!!!

reccMXlNTUReaPrhu.Name: Quickwin4.1
reccMXlNTUReaPrhu.Bottom Body:
It's time for another Quick Win! Hooray!

Today we want to talk about **naturally boosting your melatonin**! Millions of people take over-the-counter melatonin supplements every night. 

However, sleep experts recommend against this because studies have found that many supplements contain doses up to 500% more than the label indicates, there is no research assessing long-term use, and regular use my deplete your natural melatonin stores. 

So, what do you do?

reccXb9HLTSTzZzM4.Name: Overview 1.5
reccXb9HLTSTzZzM4.Bottom Body:
**A bedtime routine can help you fall asleep faster**

Bedtime routines are one of the most important things you can do to decompress at the end of the day and get your mind and body ready for sleep, as long as it doesn’t include sleep disruptors like electronics!

Design a Power Down Hour that you’ll do every night. After some consistency, your brain will associate your power down activities with bedtime which will trigger your body’s sleep signals.

Try to include things like journaling or progressive muscle relaxation to decompress.

Unplug from your electronics at least 2 hours before bed or use blue light blocking programs or blue light blocking glasses to ensure that blue light isn’t going to be energizing you when you want to be decompressing.

reccYVZ1Ar81GP7oj.Name: QuickwinFA 13.3
reccYVZ1Ar81GP7oj.Bottom Body:
**How to do Box Breathing**

Simply sit or lay down somewhere comfortable and do the following:

1. **Inhale**: Slowly inhale through your nose for the count of 4. Notice your belly pushing out as your lungs fill up with air.
2. **Hold your breath**: Hold your breath for another count of 4.
3. **Exhale**: Slowly exhale through your mouth for a count of 4.
4. **Hold your breath**: Once your lungs are empty, hold your breath again for, you guessed it, another count of 4. 

4x4x4x4 just like a box! This should make it super easy for you to remember. 

And since 4 is the magic number here, we are going to recommend you repeat it 4 times to get started. As you get better you can do it for longer!

reccZtZ1dFY0QtZwA.Name: irrationalThoughts 1.1
reccZtZ1dFY0QtZwA.Bottom Body:
**Your brain on sleep stress**
We've explained why it normal to have dramatic thoughts when you have trouble sleeping. 

A lot of people experience thoughts that are irrational or exaggerated. It can get especially bad when you can't sleep.

**For example, you may find yourself:**

• **Forecasting the future:** "I just know I'm not going to be able to sleep tonight"

• **Overgeneralizing:** "There's something seriously wrong with me, I'll never sleep well"

• **Catastrophizing:** "I'm going to get sick and die if I don't fall asleep"

These are all examples of what psychologists call **cognitive distortions**, and they can have a pretty big impact on your wellbeing.

recco2BoUvc8kdo00.Name: Exercise 1.2
recco2BoUvc8kdo00.Bottom Body:
Confusion is no fun, so we sat down with our fitness and sleep experts to learn the most valuable and practical information about the relationships between exercise and sleep

\*cue Rocky music\* We bring you, the Rested Health’s Reboot Camp guide to exercising your way to better sleep...

reccsO5412iphU9VG.Name: caffeineSleep 1.1
reccsO5412iphU9VG.Bottom Body:
**Earlier you told us that you regularly consume caffeine**. 

You aren't alone! Caffeine is the most widely consumed psychostimulant on the planet. The most popular form is coffee. Mmmmmm coffee. 

In order to make sure that you get the most out of your caffeine without it disrupting your sleep, it's best to follow some guidelines. 

Come along, let us show you the Rested Health guide to caffeine...

reccw9lAlRZ1eUljM.Name: Decompression 1.2
reccw9lAlRZ1eUljM.Bottom Body:
Developing a consistent bedtime routine acts as an environmental cue that lets your brain know it’s time to sleep. 

Your brain appreciates consistent signals and routines. 

A bedtime routine removes any confusion about “what’s next” and cues your brain to send out those sleepy-time hormones. 

You can also implement strategies within your evening ritual that help to quiet your mind, relax your body, and improve the quality of your sleep.

recd7bAYYv0wkOW2s.Name: Orientation 2.2
recd7bAYYv0wkOW2s.Bottom Body:
Over the next week, we’ll explore your:
- Sleep sanctuary 
- Environment
- Diet
- Supplement options for sleep
- How to track your sleep

As we work through each journey, we’re going to focus on 3 main goals:

1. **Reducing sleep stress**
2. **Building good habits**
3. **Reprograming conditioned arousal (remember? That’s the whole bed + sleep relationship)**

So, how are we going to do that, you ask?

Let’s find out!

recdD6kHUknEjbPhC.Name: goalsleepthrunight1.3
recdD6kHUknEjbPhC.Bottom Body:
**2. Leave the bed when you can't sleep**

It's 3am, you've awoken with all of the energy in the world but all you want to do is sleep.

**What do you do?** If you wake up during the night and can't fall back to sleep within 20 minutes – leave your bed. Staying in bed struggling with sleep will only build unhelpful associations between frustration and your bed. 

Instead – leave your bed and go do a relaxing activity in a dimly lit room. Try reading, meditating, or listening to a boring podcast. There are boring podcasts made just for this exact reason! Once you feel sleepy again, return to your bed.

**What if I can't sleep when I go back to bed?** If it's been longer than 20 minutes and you can't sleep – repeat the process again!

recdGqrtcjs9Uidzz.Name: Quickwin 8.2
recdGqrtcjs9Uidzz.Bottom Body:
**Box Breathing!**

Did you know that anytime you feel stressed you can calm your body down nearly instantly by engaging in something called **box breathing**? It can also boost your alertness! Cool, right?

**What the heck is box breathing???**

It is a technique where you engage in deep breathing in a specific pattern.

Deep breathing activates your parasympathetic nervous system which sends signals to your body to calm down!

recdHdJUisCPnefI1.Name: Circadian 1.1
recdHdJUisCPnefI1.Bottom Body:
Learning how to effectively work with your own circadian rhythm is one of the most effective approaches to improving your sleep. 

**But, what exactly is a circadian rhythm?**

Today we’re going to explore how your circadian rhythm works and the things in your environment that impact its functioning. 

Let’s begin...

recde2uHE3aE0uzJ7.Name: Mornings 1.4
recde2uHE3aE0uzJ7.Bottom Body:
**Drink a glass of water when you wake up.**

Yep, it’s that simple. 

There’s a couple of reasons this works well. First of all, it sets your day off on a good note. You’ll feel productive and you’ll check something off your list. Win-win.

Second, sleep dehydrates you, so having a glass of water will make you feel a lot better!

A glass of water as soon as you wake up in the morning (even before you brush your teeth) is an awesome way to kick off your morning.

recdide64YnxwcgFN.Name: Exercise 1.5
recdide64YnxwcgFN.Bottom Body:
But are there times when exercise interferes with sleep?

There are two ways that exercise can interfere with sleep:
1. **Raising your core temperature**
2. **Energizing you**

In general, exercise only interferes with sleep for some people when it’s done close to bedtime and when it includes intense aerobic exercise or interval training. 

Some research has found that strength training and flexibility training close to bed can actually help sleep.

We want to show you how to make sleep your superpower.

receOKDsl1Je7Cs2G.Name: goalsleepthrunight1.1
receOKDsl1Je7Cs2G.Bottom Body:
We want to help you reach your goal of sleeping through the night. 

**Defining your goal**
Waking up during the night is common. As we get older, these awakenings can become even more frequent. However, there are things you can do to limit the impact they have on your sleep and improve your sleep stability through the night. 

To get you started, we're going to talk about two things you can do to help you sleep better through the night!

1. **Mental decompression routine**
2. **Leave the bed when you can't sleep**

recebU7ibvAyUiQtO.Name: MJD Test 0.0

recf4zIiHBjBlyaSe.Name: BedtimeBasics 1.1
recf4zIiHBjBlyaSe.Bottom Body:
We want to continue on the journey of how to build a sleep sanctuary with some bedtime basics!

If we’re going to spend a third of our entire lives sleeping, we want to make sure we’re doing it somewhere comfortable, right? 

Let’s take a minute to focus on the King (or Queen) of your sleep sanctuary:

**Your Bed!**

There are so many things we could talk about when it comes to your bed, but to keep it simple for Reboot Camp, we’re just going to focus on one.

Which one will it be?

recfSdWH7EcKUSau2.Name: models  1.4
recfSdWH7EcKUSau2.Bottom Body:
**2. Consciously incompetent**: "I know I have a problem, but I don't know how to fix it"

This level will feel more familiar to a lot of people. The fact that you're here already means that you're seeking some guidance on how to level up! However, this is also the stage where many people give up.

Not you though. 

**Failure is an option:** Sometimes this stage can feel like you're going backwards because you'll be trying new things and failing. Failure is one of the most important parts of learning. 

**Fail hard and fail often!** 

**Why?** Every great discovery, change, and accomplishment included tons and tons of failure. It's the key to learning.

Figuring out what works for you and how to implement changes is a lot of trial and error! We'll support you as you work through this period of discovery.

recffPR36GByGEpJt.Name: Lighting 1.4
recffPR36GByGEpJt.Bottom Body:
**Simple fixes big results**

These basic adjustments can make it easier to create an ideal “wind-down” environment and help you avoid excessive sleep disruptions if you need to get up at night!

Plus they’re actually **so easy to implement** that you’ll be wondering why you haven’t already been doing this for years!!

You now have the basics to build a sleep sanctuary and how to set the mood for slumber. 

You may need to do a little shopping (we’ve just added 40 watt bulbs and motion sensor night lights to your list). 

But, with these simple adjustments you’ll be greatly rewarded with better sleep.

recffykMaBoRHisDP.Name: QuickwinFA 6.2
recffykMaBoRHisDP.Bottom Body:
**Make your bed!**

You may even do this already, and if you do, GO YOU!

It may sound too simple, even mundane, but it’s an effective tool. 

Making your bed as soon as you get up gives you a quick and easy opportunity to set the day off right. Before you’ve even left your room, you’ve already completed one task! Woo!

It can help you fall asleep faster too, but how?

recfqg0tJFgFvOIQn.Name: BasicsQ 1.13
recfqg0tJFgFvOIQn.Bottom Body:

recgB2DLmzLsL3aLa.Name: Overview 1.3
recgB2DLmzLsL3aLa.Bottom Body:
**A morning ritual can change your life**

Waking up at the same time every day is so important. It will help optimize all your body processes that run on a circadian rhythm.

After you wake up, participating in a morning ritual can help set a positive tone for your day, boost your overall happiness, and help you sleep better at night. 

Treat yourself to a tall glass of water and some sunshine each morning!

recgJAICxMTSpR2lU.Name: Science 1.1
recgJAICxMTSpR2lU.Bottom Body:
We’d like to talk about something important that we’ll be referencing a lot. 

Sleep architecture! 

Sleep architecture is one of the key measurements used to gauge how well you sleep. There are many devices available that measure it for you from the comfort of your own home. 

Even if you aren’t measuring it, understanding how it works can also help you understand why sometimes your sleep _feels_ better than other times.

recgXHFBm2FBabQwl.Name: relearn 1.3
recgXHFBm2FBabQwl.Bottom Body:
**1**. **Only use your bed for sleeping (and sex)**

You’ll see us mention this one again and again. This is one of the keys to rebooting your relationship with sleep and strengthening the association between bed + sleep. 

By limiting the activities you do in bed, your brain is able to clarify what your bed is for! 

We know this one is easier said than done, so we'll be here to give you some tips on how to conquer it and provide soothing habits and tricks to bring you comfort along the way.

**Let's look at the next key to rebooting your relationship with sleep...**

recgawHGvQyKfS0K7.Name: Noise 1.5
recgawHGvQyKfS0K7.Bottom Body:
**Purchase a sound machine!**

White noise, pink noise, or environmental sounds (such as wind chimes or ocean waves) are also great for blocking a great deal of noise pollution! 

They also create a calming environment that helps you relax before falling asleep!

Not only that, but pink noise has been shown to improve sleep stability by optimizing brain wave activity! Bonus!!

We promise you’ll be impressed by how helpful a sound machine can be for your sleep. They are also great for people who need to be able to hear important sounds at night (like a baby crying or a dog asking for treats at 3am for some reason).

recgbiWoLG6ubUMAS.Name: Substances 1.6
recgbiWoLG6ubUMAS.Bottom Body:
**Alcohol and sleep**
You may or may not be aware that alcohol is commonly used as a sleep aid, commonly referred to as a “nightcap".

This is because it causes a sedative effect by mimicking an important chemical messenger in your brain, called GABA. 

So, a little booze in the evening may feel like it’s helping you fall asleep, but in actuality, it is secretly wreaking havoc on your peaceful slumber. 

Want to find out how?

recgfFXrdUUBslQ4D.Name: BedtimeBasics 1.6
recgfFXrdUUBslQ4D.Bottom Body:
You already learned that your sleep sanctuary loves darkness, but what it really wants is a room that is dark **AND cool.**

Maybe you already knew your sleep thrives in a cooler temperature (you are a sleep guru in training after all).

But, if you’re someone who swears that you sleep better in a warmer room, we have some news for you...

recgkDInFquBX1xzf.Name: Oriented 1.4
